Low-Latency Federated Learning over Wireless Channels with Differential Privacy

Kang Wei  Jun Li  Chuan Ma  Ming Ding  Cailian Chen  Shi Jin  
Zhu Han  H. Vincent Poor Kang Wei, Jun Li and Chuan Ma are with School of Electrical and Optical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China (e-mail: {kang.wei, jun.li, chuan.ma}@njust.edu.cn).Ming Ding is with Data61, CSIRO, Sydney, NSW 2015, Australia (e-mail: ming.ding@data61.csiro.au).Cailian Chen is with the Department of Automation, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China, and also with Key Laboratory of System Control and Information Processing, Ministry of Education of China, Shanghai 200240, China (e-mail: cailianchen@sjtu.edu.cn).Shi Jin is with the National Mobile Communications Research Laboratory, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China (e-mail: jinshi@seu.edu.cn).Zhu Han is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in the University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004 USA, and also with the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Seoul, South Korea, (e-mail: hanzhan22@gmail.com).H. Vincent Poor is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544 USA (e-mail: poor@princeton.edu).
Abstract

In federated learning (FL), model training is distributed over clients and local models are aggregated by a central server. The performance of uploaded models in such situations can vary widely due to imbalanced data distributions, potential demands on privacy protections, and quality of transmissions. In this paper, we aim to minimize FL training delay over wireless channels, constrained by overall training performance as well as each client’s differential privacy (DP) requirement. We solve this problem in the framework of multi-agent multi-armed bandit (MAMAB) to deal with the situation where there are multiple clients confornting different unknown transmission environments, e.g., channel fading and interferences. Specifically, we first transform the long-term constraints on both training performance and each client’s DP into a virtual queue based on the Lyapunov drift technique. Then, we convert the MAMAB to a max-min bipartite matching problem at each communication round, by estimating rewards with the upper confidence bound (UCB) approach. More importantly, we propose two efficient solutions to this matching problem, i.e., modified Hungarian algorithm and greedy matching with a better alternative (GMBA), in which the first one can achieve the optimal solution with a high complexity while the second one approaches a better trade-off by enabling a verified low-complexity with little performance loss. In addition, we develop an upper bound on the expected regret of this MAMAB based FL framework, which shows a linear growth over the logarithm of communication rounds, justifying its theoretical feasibility. Extensive experimental results are conducted to validate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithms, and the impacts of various parameters on the FL performance over wireless edge networks are also discussed.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, differential privacy, multi-agent multi-armed bandit, max-min bipartite matching.

I Introduction

With the dramatic development of the Internet-of-Things (IoT), data from intelligent devices is exploding at unprecedented scales [1, 2, 3]. Meanwhile, machine learning (ML), which relies heavily on such data, is revolutionizing many aspects of our lives [4]. However, conventional centralized ML [5] offers little scalability for efficiently processing data. To tackle this challenge, several distributed ML architectures have been proposed [6]. Moreover, data privacy and confidentiality are of increasing concern as exchanged data often contain clients’ sensitive information in distributed ML settings. In this light, federated learning (FL) has been proposed, which allows decoupling of data provision at clients and machine learning model aggregation at a central server [7, 8, 9]. In FL, all clients with the same data structure collaboratively learn a shared model with the help of a central server. Owing to the local training, FL does not require clients to upload their private data, thereby effectively reducing transmission overhead as well as helping preserve clients’ privacy. As such, FL is applicable to a variety of scenarios where data are either high-cost or sensitive to be transmitted to the server, e.g., health-care records, private images, personally identifiable information, etc. [10].

Since many communication rounds are required to reach a desired model accuracy, especially when the number of participating clients in the training process is comparably large [5], the latency caused by unreliable wireless transmissions and unequal local computations at clients can be a bottleneck in wireless FL systems. Despite the computational efficiency, the long communication distance between smart devices and the remote cloud inevitably introduces a high transmission latency, resulting in an unsatisfactory user quality of experience (QoE) for delay-sensitive, especially for numerous real-time delay-sensitive applications [11, 12, 13]. The waveform-superposition property of the wireless medium has been exploited for wireless FL systems [14] to overcome the communication bottleneck. However, in many FL systems, since each client will upload its local model immediately after finishing local training, i.e., asynchronous FL, it may be difficult to utilize the superposition property of the wireless channel. Therefore, proper resource scheduling management (e.g., spectrum) plays a crucial role in improving wireless network efficiency. Especially in the envisioned sixth generation (6G) networks [15, 16], fully utilizing spectrum is expected to guarantee system performance in terms of throughput, delay, and so on.

From the perspective of resource allocation, many recent studies have focused on efficient local computation and communications between clients and edge servers in FL-supported networks [17, 18, 19, 20]. In order to characterize the performance of FL in wireless networks, an analytical model [17] in terms of FL convergence rate has been developed to evaluate the effectiveness of three different client scheduling policies, i.e., random scheduling, round-robin, and proportional fair. The work in [18] has formulated FL over a wireless network as an optimization problem and a control algorithm has been developed to minimize the loss function based on the convergence bound of distributed gradient descent. Via constructing the connection between the wireless resource allocation and the FL learning performance, the work in [19] and [21] adjusted the user selection and power allocation to minimize the FL loss function. By involving the fairness constraint for each client associated with the sizes of the local datasets [22, 23, 24], the scheduling policy becomes more efficient in terms of learning accuracy, but the sizes of the local datasets cannot represent the data distribution of the whole.

Beyond resource allocation, as a well-established mechanism for privacy-preservation of local models, differential privacy (DP) has been proposed for FL systems. Some works on DP in FL focus on the impact of DP mechanisms on learning performance under the assumption that the edge server is semi-honest and that communication is reliable (without noise and interference) and unconstrained, aiming to achieve a better tradeoff between privacy and performance [25, 26, 27]. Other works [28, 29] focus on uncoded transmission of gradients using either orthogonal or non-orthogonal protocols, and analytically demonstrate that for these transmission schemes, privacy may be obtained “for free” in the sense that enforcing a DP constraint causes no performance loss with respect to a non-private design as long as the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is sufficiently low. Unfortunately, it is not realistic or infrequent to apply the uncoded transmission in modern communication systems.

The above works do not address imbalances in clients’ characteristics, such as computing and data resources, and in this paper we consider such issues in the design of a channel assignment protocol for wireless FL systems. In particular, we propose a multi-agent multi-armed bandit (MAMAB) based policy jointly minimizing the training time and the learning performance for wireless FL systems. Our main contributions are summarized as follows.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    We investigate the problem of delay minimization for FL over wireless communication networks considering potentially different privacy protections and data imbalance. We solve this problem by a MAMAB framework with constraints on the overall training performance and each client’s DP requirement.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    We transform the long-term constraint of the MAMAB problem on the training performance and DP requirements into a virtual queue based on Lyapunov technique, and then use the upper confidence bound (UCB) method for estimating of rewards in MAMAB. Based on this estimate, we can schedule clients at each communication round by solving a max-min bipartite matching problem with two efficient solutions. The first solution can achieve the optimal matching result but a high complexity and the second one can achieve a lower complexity with little performance loss.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    We perform an analysis of the feasibility of the proposed MAMAB based FL framework. We show that the optimality gap of the proposed agent-based collaborative MAMAB framework is given by O​(V2​N​log⁡T)𝑂superscript𝑉2𝑁𝑇O(V^{2}N\log T), where V2superscript𝑉2V^{2} is attributed to the impact of the client participating ratio constraint, and N𝑁N and log⁡T𝑇\log T are, respectively, attributed to the cost of communication and computation dynamics in the learning process. In particular, N𝑁N and T𝑇T are denoted as the number of available channels and the number of communication rounds, respectively.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Extensive experimental results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm in terms of feasibility. Moreover, we show that our proposed algorithms can fully exploit the interplay between communication and computation to outperform the baselines.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we give the system model of wireless FL model with imbalanced resources among clients. Then, we formulate the joint channel assignment problem as an optimization problem whose goal is to minimize the time delay and propose the MAMAB based algorithm in Section IV. In Section V, we propose solutions to the max-min weighted bipartite matching problem. We perform an analysis of the feasibility of the proposed algorithm in VI. Experimental results are described in Section VII. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section VIII.

II System Model

Fig. 1 shows a dynamic FL system consisting of a base station (BS) with a central server, U𝑈U clients and N𝑁N available channels, to train a global model by fully utilizing all clients’ data during T𝑇T communication rounds. In each communication round, the selected clients can communicate with the BS through assigned channels, which are subject to interference caused by wireless equipment in other service areas. We can note that each chosen client i𝑖i consists of a local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, ∀i∈𝒰for-all𝑖𝒰\forall i\in\mathcal{U}, 𝒰={1,2,…,U}𝒰12…𝑈\mathcal{U}=\{1,2,\ldots,U\}. These datasets are independent from client to client. The training process of such an FL system can be summarized as follows: 1) The central server broadcasts the global model and training information (e.g., channel assignment) to all clients. 2) Each client updates their respective models with the global model, and tests the performance of the updated models. 3) Each client performs the local training procedure based on its local dataset, and sends the trained local model parameters to the central server. 4) The server performs aggregation over the uploaded models from clients, and begins the next communication round until the terminal condition is reached. The central server aggregates the models received from the clients, which can be given as

𝒘​(t)=∑i∈𝒮​(t)pi​𝒘i​(t),𝒘𝑡subscript𝑖𝒮𝑡subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}(t)=\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{S}(t)}p_{i}\bm{w}_{i}(t), (1)

where 𝒮​(t)𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}(t) is the set of clients that successfully upload their local models, pi=|𝒟i|/∑i∈𝒮​(t)|𝒟i|subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑖𝒮𝑡subscript𝒟𝑖p_{i}=|\mathcal{D}_{i}|/\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}(t)}|\mathcal{D}_{i}|, 𝒘​(t)𝒘𝑡\bm{w}(t) is the global model at the t𝑡t-th communication round, and 𝒘i​(t)subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}(t) is the uploaded model of the i𝑖i-th client at the t𝑡t-th communication round. The goal of FL is to learn a model over data that resides at the U𝑈U associated clients. Formally, this FL task can be expressed as

𝒘⋆=arg⁡min𝒘F​(𝒘),superscript𝒘⋆subscript𝒘𝐹𝒘\bm{w}^{\star}=\mathop{\arg\min}_{\bm{w}}{F(\bm{w})}, (2)

where F​(𝒘)=∑i∈𝒰pi​Fi​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘subscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘F(\bm{w})=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}}p_{i}F_{i}(\bm{w}) and Fi​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F_{i}(\cdot) is the local objective function of the i𝑖i-th client. From this FL training procedure, we observe that all clients with the same data structure collaboratively learn a ML model with the help of a central server. After a sufficient number of local training and update exchanges between the server and its associated clients, the solution to the optimization problem is able to converge to the global optimal learning model.

II-A Transmission Model

Due to the core network connection, we assume that the overall training delay does not include the transmission time between the BS and the central server, i.e., the delay in backhauls is ignored. We can note that the interference caused by the wireless equipments that are located in other service areas in the uplink or downlink channel is governed by the applied channel and the location of the receiver. Thus, in this FL system, the uplink data rate of the i𝑖i-th client transmitting its local model to the BS via the j𝑗j-channel at the t𝑡t-th communication round can be expressed as

Ri,jU​(t)=BU​log2⁡{1+PU​hi,j​(t)Ii,jU​(t)+σ2},superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗U𝑡superscript𝐵Usubscript21superscript𝑃Usubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐼U𝑖𝑗𝑡superscript𝜎2R_{i,j}^{\text{U}}(t)=B^{\text{U}}\log_{2}\left\{1+\frac{P^{\text{U}}h_{i,j}(t)}{I^{\text{U}}_{i,j}(t)+\sigma^{2}}\right\}, (3)

where PUsuperscript𝑃UP^{\text{U}} is the transmit power for clients, hi,j​(t)subscriptℎ𝑖𝑗𝑡h_{i,j}(t) is the average channel gain from the i𝑖i-th client to the BS via the j𝑗j-th channel, Ii,jU​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐼U𝑖𝑗𝑡I^{\text{U}}_{i,j}(t) is the co-channel interference caused by the wireless equipments that are located in other service areas, σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is the noise power spectral density, and BUsuperscript𝐵UB^{\text{U}} is the bandwidth of the uplink channel.

Similarly, for the downlink, when the central server transmits the global model parameters to the i𝑖i-th client, the data rate of the BS via the j𝑗j-th channel at the t𝑡t-th communication round is given by

Ri,jD​(t)=BD​log2⁡{1+PD​hi,j​(t)Ii,jD​(t)+σ2},superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗D𝑡superscript𝐵Dsubscript21superscript𝑃Dsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐼D𝑖𝑗𝑡superscript𝜎2R_{i,j}^{\text{D}}(t)=B^{\text{D}}\log_{2}\left\{1+\frac{P^{\text{D}}h_{i,j}(t)}{I^{\text{D}}_{i,j}(t)+\sigma^{2}}\right\}, (4)

where PDsuperscript𝑃DP^{\text{D}} is the transmit power for the BS, BDsuperscript𝐵DB^{\text{D}} is the bandwidth of the downlink channel and Ii,jD​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐼D𝑖𝑗𝑡I^{\text{D}}_{i,j}(t) is the interference caused by other wireless equipments not participating in the FL training process. Given the uplink data rate in (3) and the downlink data rate in (4), we can derive the uplink and downlink transmission delays, respectively. Since the number of elements in the local FL model 𝒘i​(t)subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}(t) is equal to that of the global FL model 𝒘​(t)𝒘𝑡\bm{w}(t). The transmission delay between client i𝑖i and the j𝑗j-th channel over both uplink and downlink at the t𝑡t-th communication round can be, respectively, computed as

di,jU​(t)=Z​(𝒘i​(t))Ri,jU​(t),di,jD​(t)=Z​(𝒘​(t))Ri,jD​(t),formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑑U𝑖𝑗𝑡𝑍subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗U𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑑D𝑖𝑗𝑡𝑍𝒘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗D𝑡d^{\text{U}}_{i,j}(t)=\frac{Z(\bm{w}_{i}(t))}{R_{i,j}^{\text{U}}(t)},\,\,d^{\text{D}}_{i,j}(t)=\frac{Z(\bm{w}(t))}{R_{i,j}^{\text{D}}(t)}, (5)

where function Z​(𝒘)𝑍𝒘Z(\bm{w}) is the data size of 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} which is defined as the number of bits that the client or the BS require to transmit vector 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} over wireless links. To this end, the scheduling policy plays a crucial role of assigning the resource-limited radio available channels to the appropriate clients.

II-B Computation Model

In the computation model, we assume each client is equipped with an CPU for the training task. We measure the computation capacity of each client by its CPU frequency, denoted by fi​(t)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑡f_{i}(t) (in CPU cycle/s) , which is changed at the t𝑡t-th communication round. Moreover, let ΦisubscriptΦ𝑖\Phi_{i} denote the number of CPU cycles performing the forward-backward propagation algorithm with one data for the i𝑖i-th client. Due to the fact that CPU operates in the serial mode, the local gradient calculation latency is given by diL​(t)=τ​|𝒟i|​Φi/fi​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑑L𝑖𝑡𝜏subscript𝒟𝑖subscriptΦ𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝑡d^{\text{L}}_{i}(t)=\tau|\mathcal{D}_{i}|\Phi_{i}/f_{i}(t), where τ𝜏\tau is the local training iterations. We can note that there exists a tradeoff between the learning performance and local training delay.

II-C Differential Privacy

The DP mechanism with parameters ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and δ𝛿\delta provides a strong criterion for the privacy preservation of distributed data processing systems. Here, ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 is the distinguishable bound on all outputs on neighboring datasets x,x′𝑥superscript𝑥′x,x^{\prime} in a database 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, and δ𝛿\delta represents the probability of the event that the ratio of the probabilities for two adjacent datasets x,x′𝑥superscript𝑥′x,x^{\prime} cannot be bounded by eϵsuperscript𝑒italic-ϵe^{\epsilon} after adding a privacy-preserving mechanism. With an arbitrarily given δ𝛿\delta, a larger ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon gives a clearer distinguishability of neighboring datasets and thus a higher risk of privacy violation. Now, we will formally define DP as follows.

Definition 1.

((ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP [30]): A randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP: 𝒳→ℛ→𝒳ℛ\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} with domain 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and range ℛℛ\mathcal{R}, if for all measurable sets 𝒴⊆ℛ𝒴ℛ\mathcal{Y}\subseteq\mathcal{R} and any two adjacent datasets, i.e., ∀x,x′∈𝒳for-all𝑥superscript𝑥′𝒳\forall x,x^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}, we have Pr​[ℳ​(x)∈𝒴]≤eϵ​Pr​[ℳ​(x′)∈𝒴]+δPrdelimited-[]ℳ𝑥𝒴superscript𝑒italic-ϵPrdelimited-[]ℳsuperscript𝑥′𝒴𝛿\emph{Pr}[\mathcal{M}(x)\in\mathcal{Y}]\leq e^{\epsilon}\emph{Pr}[\mathcal{M}(x^{\prime})\in\mathcal{Y}]+\delta.

We can notice that central DP (CDP) and local DP (LDP) are both discussed in FL [31] and they are applied for different threat models. CDP in FL is utilized for the condition that there may exist an adversary, who can access to the global model, and infer that whether a client exists in the whole training process. In our model, we consider the curious-but-honest server and intend to preserve the privacy of each user’s data xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} in the local setting, which belongs to LDP. Thus, we define the neighborhood dataset xi′subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑖x^{\prime}_{i} as adding or removing one record in the dataset xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}, ∀xi,xi′for-allsubscript𝑥𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑖\forall x_{i},x^{\prime}_{i} in a database 𝒳isubscript𝒳𝑖\mathcal{X}_{i}. The formal definition of (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP for the i𝑖i-th user is as follows.

Definition 2.

((ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP [32]): For the i𝑖i-th client, a randomized mechanism ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i} satisfies (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP: 𝒳i→ℛi→subscript𝒳𝑖subscriptℛ𝑖\mathcal{X}_{i}\rightarrow\mathcal{R}_{i} with domain 𝒳isubscript𝒳𝑖\mathcal{X}_{i} and range ℛisubscriptℛ𝑖\mathcal{R}_{i}, if for all measurable sets 𝒴i⊆ℛisubscript𝒴𝑖subscriptℛ𝑖\mathcal{Y}_{i}\subseteq\mathcal{R}_{i} and any two adjacent datasets ∀xi,xi′∈𝒳ifor-allsubscript𝑥𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑖subscript𝒳𝑖\forall x_{i},x^{\prime}_{i}\in\mathcal{X}_{i}, we have Pr​[ℳi​(xi)∈𝒴i]≤eϵi​Pr​[ℳi​(xi′)∈𝒴i]+δiPrdelimited-[]subscriptℳ𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝒴𝑖superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖Prdelimited-[]subscriptℳ𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑖subscript𝒴𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖\emph{Pr}[\mathcal{M}_{i}(x_{i})\in\mathcal{Y}_{i}]\leq e^{\epsilon_{i}}\emph{Pr}[\mathcal{M}_{i}(x^{\prime}_{i})\in\mathcal{Y}_{i}]+\delta_{i}.

The perturbation mechanism ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i} is applied to each user’s dataset independently. Gaussian mechanism has been widely used in the privacy preserving stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithms [4] to protect users’ privacy during training. Therefore, we adopt the Gaussian mechanism in this paper, which can satisfy (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP for the i𝑖i-th client when we properly select the value of the standard deviation (STD) σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i}. Based on [27], each client can achieve the (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP requirement with a proper σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i}, where (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i}) is the LDP parameter for the i𝑖i-th client and Δ​ℓiΔsubscriptℓ𝑖\Delta\ell_{i} is the sensitivity of local training process.

Due to the varying channel, the unknown interference and the stochastic scheduling scheme, the exposure time for each client cannot be obtained in advance. Therefore, we only consider the LDP for each client in each communication round. Nevertheless, we can obtain the composition of leakage ϵ¯isubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖\overline{\epsilon}_{i} based on the local privacy leakage according to [33] in each communication round as follows:

ϵ¯i=Ei​ln⁡(1δi)ln⁡(2δi)​ϵi,subscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝐸𝑖1subscript𝛿𝑖2subscript𝛿𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\overline{\epsilon}_{i}=\sqrt{\frac{E_{i}\ln(\frac{1}{\delta_{i}})}{\ln(\frac{2}{\delta_{i}})}}\epsilon_{i}, (6)

where Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i} is the times of the model uploading for the i𝑖i-th client and can be obtained at each communication round.

II-D Problem Formulation

According to the aforementioned analysis, the time cost of the i𝑖i-th client at the t𝑡t-th communication round depends on three main components: broadcasting time, local training time, and uploading time, denoted by di,jD​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑗D𝑡d_{i,j}^{\text{D}}(t), diL​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑑L𝑖𝑡d^{\text{L}}_{i}(t), and di,jU​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑗U𝑡d_{i,j}^{\text{U}}(t), respectively. Since the central server has abundant computational resources compared to the clients, the latency incurred by global model aggregation is negligible. Thus, the total time consumed by the i𝑖i-th client at the t𝑡t-th round is given as di,j​(t)=di,jD​(t)+di,jU​(t)+diL​(t)subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑗D𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑗U𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑑L𝑖𝑡d_{i,j}(t)=d_{i,j}^{\text{D}}(t)+d_{i,j}^{\text{U}}(t)+d^{\text{L}}_{i}(t). Here, we define dmaxsubscript𝑑maxd_{\text{max}} as the maximal interval of each communication round, which is used to avoid an endless waiting time caused by possible stragglers. We can observe that our model is consistent with the asynchronous FL described in [34]. This asynchronous setting is to guarantee the predefined system delay requirement. The time that the clients and the BS with N𝑁N available channels require to jointly complete an update of their respective local and global FL models at t𝑡t-th communication round is given by d​(t)=maxi∈𝒰⁡{min⁡{di,j​(t),dmax}}𝑑𝑡subscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑡subscript𝑑maxd(t)=\max_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\{\min\left\{d_{i,j}(t),d_{\text{max}}\right\}\}. Thus, it is crucial to control the largest delay among all clients. Having defined the system model, the next step is to design the dynamic channel assigning mechanisms in this work to minimize the time delay while competing the FL training. This optimization problem is formulated as follows:

P1:min𝒂​(1)​…​𝒂​(T)​∑t∈𝒯d​(t),P1:subscript𝒂1…𝒂𝑇subscript𝑡𝒯𝑑𝑡\displaystyle\textbf{P1:}\quad\min_{\bm{a}(1)\ldots\bm{a}(T)}\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}d(t),
s.t. C1:​ai,j​(t)∈{0,1},∀i∈𝒰,j∈𝒩,formulae-sequenceC1:subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡01formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖𝒰𝑗𝒩\displaystyle\textbf{C1:}~{}a_{i,j}(t)\in\{0,1\},\forall i\in\mathcal{U},j\in\mathcal{N},

where βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} is the participating ratio for the i𝑖i-th client determined by its DP requirement (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i}) and local training model 𝒘i​(t)subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{w}_{i}(t), which will be discussed detailly in the following section, 𝒂​(t)𝒂𝑡\bm{a}(t) is a selection matrix with size U×N𝑈𝑁U\times N at t𝑡t-th communication round111Here we assume that U≥N𝑈𝑁U\geq N. If U<N𝑈𝑁U<N, we can use a transposed matrix, i.e., 𝒂​(t)⊤𝒂superscript𝑡top\bm{a}(t)^{\top}., in which ai,j​(t)=1subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡1a_{i,j}(t)=1 means the i𝑖i-th client is assigned to the j𝑗j-th channel and 𝟙i​(t)subscript1𝑖𝑡\mathds{1}_{i}(t) denotes an indicator function, which means whether the local training model of the i𝑖i-th client has successfully received by the server at the t𝑡t-th communication round, that is, if it is true, 𝟙i​(t)=1subscript1𝑖𝑡1\mathds{1}_{i}(t)=1, otherwise 𝟙i​(t)=0subscript1𝑖𝑡0\mathds{1}_{i}(t)=0. The domains of the variables in 𝒂​(t)𝒂𝑡\bm{a}(t) are defined by C1. Constraints C2 and C3 are maximum matching constraints, which control collisions among different clients [27]. The constraint C4 is adopted to guarantee the participating ratio for various clients. From P1, we can find that the time used for the update of the local and global FL models is determined by the allocation matrix 𝒂​(t)𝒂𝑡\bm{a}(t) from clients to available channels. We consider a practical condition that the central server is unaware of wireless channel state information and statistical characteristics. In consequence, the time duration of local training and the time delay induced by model transmission are unavailable. Hence, it is challenging to solve problem P1.

III Learning Performance Bound with DP and Data Imbalance

In this section, we will derive a learning convergence bound to determine the client’s participating ratio. Investigating the convergence performance of FL training relies on three aspects: the number of rounds taken to reach a target accuracy, the number of participant clients for each training round and the data distribution of participant clients. The rationale behind FL is that when local epochs τ=1𝜏1\tau=1, i.e., when we perform global aggregation after every local update step, the distributed gradient descent is equivalent to the centralized gradient descent. Consequently, we evaluate the FL training performance by formulating the divergence between the i𝑖i-th uploaded model 𝒘~i​(t)subscriptbold-~𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{\widetilde{w}}_{i}(t), where 𝒘~i​(t)=𝒘i​(t)+𝒏i​(t)subscriptbold-~𝒘𝑖𝑡subscript𝒘𝑖𝑡subscript𝒏𝑖𝑡\bm{\widetilde{w}}_{i}(t)=\bm{w}_{i}(t)+\bm{n}_{i}(t) and 𝒏i​(t)subscript𝒏𝑖𝑡\bm{n}_{i}(t) is the additive Gaussian noise generated by the STD σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i}, and the centralized training model 𝒘^​(t)bold-^𝒘𝑡\bm{\widehat{w}}(t) at the t𝑡t-th communication round, referred to as distributed model divergence. To this end, we formally bound the distributed model divergence as the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

We assume that Fi​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F_{i}(\cdot) is λmsubscript𝜆𝑚\lambda_{m}-Lipschitz smooth for m𝑚m-class samples for all clients, where m∈{1,…,M}𝑚1…𝑀m\in\{1,\ldots,M\}. The divergence between 𝐰​(t)𝐰𝑡\bm{w}(t) and 𝐰^​(t)bold-^𝐰𝑡\bm{\widehat{w}}(t) at the t𝑡t-th communication round can be written as

𝔼𝔼\displaystyle\mathbb{E} {‖𝒘~i​(t)−𝒘^​(t)‖}≤Θi≜∑j=0τ−1(1+η​λmax)jnormsubscriptbold-~𝒘𝑖𝑡bold-^𝒘𝑡subscriptΘ𝑖≜superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝜏1superscript1𝜂subscript𝜆max𝑗\displaystyle\{\left\|\bm{\widetilde{w}}_{i}(t)-\bm{\widehat{w}}(t)\right\|\}\leq\Theta_{i}\triangleq\sum_{j=0}^{\tau-1}\left(1+\eta\lambda_{\emph{max}}\right)^{j} (7)
(η​C​∑m=1M‖pi,m−qm‖+4​η​C​qi​2​τ​ln⁡(1/δi)π​bi​ϵi),𝜂𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝑀𝑚1normsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑚subscript𝑞𝑚4𝜂𝐶subscript𝑞𝑖2𝜏1subscript𝛿𝑖𝜋subscript𝑏𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\displaystyle\left(\eta C\sum^{M}_{m=1}\|p_{i,m}-q_{m}\|+\frac{4\eta Cq_{i}\sqrt{2\tau\ln(1/\delta_{i})}}{\sqrt{\pi}b_{i}\epsilon_{i}}\right),

where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate for SGD, bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} is the sampling size for each local epoch, qi=bi/|𝒟i|subscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖q_{i}=b_{i}/|\mathcal{D}_{i}| is the sampling rate, C𝐶C is an upper bound on the norm of the gradient ‖∇F​(⋅)‖norm∇𝐹⋅\|\nabla F(\cdot)\|, λmax=maxm∈{1,…,M}⁡λmsubscript𝜆maxsubscript𝑚1…𝑀subscript𝜆𝑚\lambda_{\emph{max}}=\max_{m\in\{1,\ldots,M\}}\lambda_{m}, pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} is the sample ratio of the i𝑖i-th client in all samples, and pi,msubscript𝑝𝑖𝑚p_{i,m} is the ratio of m𝑚m-class samples in the i𝑖i-th client, respectively.

Proof:

Please see Appendix A.

From Theorem 1, we can note that the divergence between 𝒘~i​(t)subscriptbold-~𝒘𝑖𝑡\bm{\widetilde{w}}_{i}(t) and 𝒘^​(t)bold-^𝒘𝑡\bm{\widehat{w}}(t) is governed by two terms. The first term indicates that if pi,msubscript𝑝𝑖𝑚p_{i,m} is similar to qmsubscript𝑞𝑚q_{m}, for all m𝑚m and i𝑖i, we will have a small divergence. An client’s data is more useful for the learning if its distribution better represents the overall data distribution. Besides, we can find that the divergence increases with the value of τ𝜏\tau. The second term shows the effect of DP requirement, in which a larger ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} will lead to a larger divergence.

Then, we take the user-specific measurements out of (7), and then the participating ratio [24, 23, 22] for the i𝑖i-th client can be determined by

βi=min⁡{N⋅1/Θi∑u∈𝒰1/Θu,1}.subscript𝛽𝑖⋅𝑁1subscriptΘ𝑖subscript𝑢𝒰1subscriptΘ𝑢1\beta_{i}=\min\left\{N\cdot\frac{1/\Theta_{i}}{\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}}1/\Theta_{u}},1\right\}. (8)

Combining with (7), we can note that if ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} is larger, then βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} will be larger due to less noise on the i𝑖i-th local model. This participating ratio βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} derived by the convergence bound of the i𝑖i-th client is introduced to show the number of communication rounds in which the i𝑖i-th client participates. Based on this participating ratio βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} for each client, we can optimize the communication resources while taking learning performance into account by utilizing the participating ratio as the constraint. In other word, we apply this bound as the constraint in optimizing the accumulated delay to achieve a balance between the training performance and delay. Superior to the fairness guarantee [24, 23, 22], we can note that this constraint can not only avoid the occurrence of abandoning the slow but important clients due to the pursuit of low delay, but also involve the important clients in more rounds by setting a large participating ratio.

IV Collaborative MAMAB Based FL

Our goal is to design allocation strategies online to minimize the accumulated transmission delay over a time horizon T𝑇T when wireless channel conditions and the computation capability (i.e., available CPU frequencies in II-B) are unknown. In our framework, we adopt multi-armed bandit (MAB) to optimize the client scheduling by learning statistical property of the interference and the computation capability from the unknown environment, thereby minimizing the overall delay. Since there are multiple clients confornting different unknown transmission environments, we adopt the MAMAB framework to deal with this situation. Thus, in this section, we will model this FL training optimization problem as a sequential multi-agent decision making problem and reformulate this problem as a MAMAB problem

IV-A Multi-agent Multi-armed Bandit Reformulation

At the t𝑡t-th communication round, the chosen j𝑗j-th channel for the i𝑖i-th client is referred to as a super arm. Hence, the i𝑖i-th client, i∈𝒰𝑖𝒰i\in\mathcal{U}, is assigned to the j𝑗j-th channel, j∈𝒩𝑗𝒩j\in\mathcal{N}, which specifies the selected channel and observes its reward ri,j​(t)subscript𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑡r_{i,j}(t). The reward can be defined as ri,j​(t)≜max⁡{1−di,j​(t)/dmax,0}≜subscript𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑡1subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑡subscript𝑑max0r_{i,j}(t)\triangleq\max\{1-d_{i,j}(t)/d_{\text{max}},0\}, where dmaxsubscript𝑑maxd_{\text{max}}. The reward ri,j​(t)subscript𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑡r_{i,j}(t) transforms the time delay di,j​(t)subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑡d_{i,j}(t) into a selection reward and if di,j​(t)subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑡d_{i,j}(t) is larger than dmaxsubscript𝑑maxd_{\text{max}}, the system is set to receive a zero-reward. Clients who have timed will be dropped and will not participant in the aggregation in each communication round. The server will start the next communication round and transmit the global model to all clients after completing the aggregation process. The general reward r​(t)𝑟𝑡r(t) related with all users at the t𝑡t-th communication round can be given as

r^​(t)=mini∈𝒰​∑j∈𝒩ri,j​(t)​ai,j​(t).^𝑟𝑡subscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑗𝒩subscript𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑡subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡\displaystyle\hat{r}(t)=\min_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}r_{i,j}(t)a_{i,j}(t). (9)

Moreover, selecting clients is not only to find clients with good channels to quickly complete the communication round but also to identify clients with valuable data contributions to the learning itself. Thus, by considering the participating ratio βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i}, the objective function can be reformulated as

P2:max𝒂​(1)​…​𝒂​(T)​∑t∈𝒯r^​(t),s.t.​C1,C2,C3,C4.P2:subscript𝒂1…𝒂𝑇subscript𝑡𝒯^𝑟𝑡s.t.C1C2C3C4\displaystyle\textbf{P2:}\quad\max_{\bm{a}(1)\ldots\bm{a}(T)}\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\hat{r}(t),\,\text{s.t.}~{}\textbf{C1},\textbf{C2},\textbf{C3},\textbf{C4}.

We can note that optimization problem P2 is a MAMAB problem, where each client acts as an agent and each channel acts as an arm. The server determines the channel assigning strategy based on its cumulative knowledge to maximize the accumulated reward with unknown distributions of the reward. We can solve the optimization problem P2 by estimating the reward and then designing the assigning strategy at each communication round.

IV-B Virtual Queue and One-Slot Optimization Problem

In this subsection, we aim to solve P2. It can be noted that P2 is a stochastic optimization problem under an unknown environment with a long-term constraint C4. According to [35], the long-term constraint C4 in P2 can be transformed into part of the objective function in P3. This transformation is sufficient and necessary. First, we can leverage the Lyapunov technique and transform constraint C4 into queue stability constraints [36]. In detail, we introduce virtual queues Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} with the following update equation: Qi​(t)=[Qi​(t−1)+βi−𝟙i​(t−1)]+subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡1subscript𝛽𝑖subscript1𝑖𝑡1Q_{i}(t)=[Q_{i}(t-1)+\beta_{i}-\mathds{1}_{i}(t-1)]^{+}, where [x]+≜max⁡{x,0}≜superscriptdelimited-[]𝑥𝑥0[x]^{+}\triangleq\max\{x,0\}. We can note 𝟙i​(t−1)subscript1𝑖𝑡1\mathds{1}_{i}(t-1) increases when the i𝑖i-th client’s local model is received by the server timely. Then, we define

r~i​(t)≜V​∑j∈𝒩ri,j​(t)​ai,j​(t)+Qi​(t),≜subscript~𝑟𝑖𝑡𝑉subscript𝑗𝒩subscript𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑡subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\widetilde{r}_{i}(t)\triangleq V\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}r_{i,j}(t)a_{i,j}(t)+Q_{i}(t), (10)

where V≥0𝑉0V\geq 0 strikes a balance between learning performance and delay experience. As can be seen in the above queue-length evolution, the value of the virtual queue to the i𝑖i-th client increases by βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} in each round as βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} is the minimum selection fraction, and it decreases by one if the i𝑖i-th client is uploading its model successfully.

Under the framework of Lyapunov optimization, we further resort to the drift-plus-penalty algorithm and solve the following optimization problem to determine channel allocation as

P3:max𝒂​(1)​…​𝒂​(T)P3:subscript𝒂1…𝒂𝑇\displaystyle\textbf{P3:}\quad\max_{\bm{a}(1)\ldots\bm{a}(T)} ∑t=1Tmini∈𝒰⁡r~i​(t),s.t.​C1,C2,C3.superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝑖𝒰subscript~𝑟𝑖𝑡s.t.C1C2C3\displaystyle\sum_{t=1}^{T}\min_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\widetilde{r}_{i}(t),\,\text{s.t.}~{}\textbf{C1},\textbf{C2},\textbf{C3}.

Note that P3 can be divided into T𝑇T independent sub-optimization problems, for each communication round, the client selection strategy is optimized with the estimated reward based on the historical reward observations. The objective of P3 is to maximize the accumulated reward over a time horizon based on its cumulative knowledge. Therefore, there exists a tradeoff between exploration (i.e., assigning all available channels a sufficient number of times to estimate the reward more accurately) and exploitation (i.e., assigning available channels to maximize the estimated reward).

IV-C Solution for Agent-Based Collaborative MAMAB

In order to solve P3, we now consider this MAMAB problem with i.i.d. rewards wherein multiple clients select available channels at the same time. The server and clients have no information about expectations or distribution of rewards from various available channels. Therefore, it is observed that the total reward function can be decomposed into a cumulative sum of minimum local agent-dependent reward functions for overall communication rounds. Instead of utilizing the average reward straightforwardly, we define the estimated reward by adding a perturbed term to the average reward [37], which can achieve a good tradeoff between exploration and exploitation. For the i𝑖i-th client and the j𝑗j-th channel, we can obtain the estimated reward at the end of the t𝑡t-th communication round as

ei,j​(t)subscript𝑒𝑖𝑗𝑡\displaystyle e_{i,j}(t) =Qi​(t)+V​r¯i,j​(t)absentsubscript𝑄𝑖𝑡𝑉subscript¯𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑡\displaystyle=Q_{i}(t)+V\overline{r}_{i,j}(t) (11)
+V​(U+2)​log⁡(∑u=0t−1∑j∈𝒩ai,j​(u))∑u=0t−1ai,j​(u),𝑉𝑈2superscriptsubscript𝑢0𝑡1subscript𝑗𝒩subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑢0𝑡1subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑢\displaystyle\quad+V\sqrt{\frac{(U+2)\log(\sum_{u=0}^{t-1}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}a_{i,j}(u))}{\sum_{u=0}^{t-1}a_{i,j}(u)}},

where r¯i,j​(t)subscript¯𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑡\overline{r}_{i,j}(t) is the sample mean of rewards from the j𝑗j-th channel for the i𝑖i-th client at the t𝑡t-th communication round and given by

r¯i,j​(t)=∑u=0t−1ai,j​(u)​ri,j​(u)∑u=0t−1ai,j​(u).subscript¯𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑢0𝑡1subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑢subscript𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑢0𝑡1subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑢\overline{r}_{i,j}(t)=\frac{\sum_{u=0}^{t-1}a_{i,j}(u)r_{i,j}(u)}{\sum_{u=0}^{t-1}a_{i,j}(u)}. (12)

Note that this perturbed term corresponds to the UCB in MAMAB, which is utilized in the combinatorial MAMAB problem [37].

With the estimated reward, we can optimize the channel assigning strategy by maximizing the total estimated reward at each time slot t𝑡t. In this case, we summarize the detailed steps in Algorithm 1. Different from the conventional FL framework, Algorithm 1 is designed that central server will transmit the matching result 𝒂​(t)𝒂𝑡\bm{a}(t) to all clients at the beginning of each communication round along with the global model based on the estimated reward ei,j​(t)subscript𝑒𝑖𝑗𝑡e_{i,j}(t), i∈𝒰𝑖𝒰i\in\mathcal{U}, j∈𝒩𝑗𝒩j\in\mathcal{N}. In addition, each client can upload an extra bit of information to the server to indicate the received time of the global model along with uploading local model, and we neglect the extra time consuming here. Meanwhile, the server is able to update the estimated reward ei,j​(t)subscript𝑒𝑖𝑗𝑡e_{i,j}(t). We can observe that T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} is utilized to achieve a tradeoff between the exploitation of learned knowledge and the exploration of more potential actions.

Compared with the single-agent MAB problem, the main difficulty of the MAMAB problem is that there exists collisions among different agents. At this point, with the estimated reward ei,j​(t)subscript𝑒𝑖𝑗𝑡e_{i,j}(t) for all clients, we can note that the key of this algorithm is how to complete the max-min weighted bipartite matching at each communication round (obtain 𝒂​(t)𝒂𝑡\bm{a}(t)). In the following section, we will propose solutions for this problem.

V Solutions for Max-min Weighted Matching

At each communication round, with the estimated reward ei,j​(t)subscript𝑒𝑖𝑗𝑡e_{i,j}(t), we can complete clients scheduling by solving a bipartite matching for all clients and available channels to obtain a required delay. However, different from the conventional matching problem for a maximum cumulative reward, the target matching problem aims to maximize the minimum Ri​(t)subscript𝑅𝑖𝑡R_{i}(t), i∈𝒰𝑖𝒰i\in\mathcal{U}. Formally, a mathematical model for this problem transformed from P3 can be expressed as

P4:max𝒂​(t)⁡mini∈𝒰P4:subscript𝒂𝑡subscript𝑖𝒰\displaystyle\textbf{P4:}\quad\max_{\bm{a}(t)}\min_{i\in\mathcal{U}} ∑j∈𝒩ai,j​(t)​ei,j​(t),s.t.​C1,C2,C3.subscript𝑗𝒩subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡subscript𝑒𝑖𝑗𝑡s.t.C1C2C3\displaystyle\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}a_{i,j}(t)e_{i,j}(t),\quad\text{s.t.}~{}\textbf{C1},\textbf{C2},\textbf{C3}.

The objective function in P4 maximizes the value of the minimum estimated reward of all clients, i.e., ∑j∈𝒩ai,j​(t)​ei,j​(t)subscript𝑗𝒩subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡subscript𝑒𝑖𝑗𝑡\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}a_{i,j}(t)e_{i,j}(t), over all possible matchings. We can note that, in this problem, there is a complete weighted bipartite graph 𝒢=(𝒰,𝒩,ℰ)𝒢𝒰𝒩ℰ\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{U},\mathcal{N},\mathcal{E}), where 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} and 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} are the sets of clients and channels, respectively, and ℰℰ\mathcal{E} is the set of edges which value is corresponding to ei,j​(t)subscript𝑒𝑖𝑗𝑡e_{i,j}(t).

V-A Modified Hungarian Algorithm

With a standard Hungarian algorithm [38], we can find the perfect matching with maximum cumulative rewards. Therefore, for the max-min weighted matching, we can prune the minimum edge of graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, and then try to search a perfect matching with the updated 𝒢′superscript𝒢′\mathcal{G}^{\prime}. If we obtain the perfect matching successfully, we will prune the minimum edge and search a perfect matching consecutively. Otherwise, we output the perfect matching as the final result. In this way, we can complete the max-min weighted matching and term it as optimal matching (OM).

V-B Greedy Matching with a Better Alternative

In this subsection, we introduce a modified greedy algorithm, termed greedy matching with a better alternative (GMBA) algorithm, which can achieve a verified low-complexity. Algorithm 2 characterizes the procedure of the GMBA algorithm. At the t𝑡t-th communication round, the server can possess the previous matching result 𝒂​(t−1)𝒂𝑡1\bm{a}(t-1) and the estimated reward ei,j​(t)subscript𝑒𝑖𝑗𝑡e_{i,j}(t), ∀i∈𝒰for-all𝑖𝒰\forall i\in\mathcal{U}. At the beginning, the server initializes a client set 𝒜={1,…,N}𝒜1…𝑁\mathcal{A}=\{1,\ldots,N\}, which includes all clients and an all zero matrix 𝒂^​(t)bold-^𝒂𝑡\bm{\hat{a}}(t). The server randomly selects an greedy order from the set of all orders, i.e., 𝒐∈𝒪𝒐𝒪\bm{o}\in\mathcal{O} and assigns available channels to all clients. Here, we define 𝒐𝒐\bm{o} as a sequence of clients (𝒐1,…,𝒐U)subscript𝒐1…subscript𝒐𝑈(\bm{o}_{1},\ldots,\bm{o}_{U}) such that 𝒐i∈𝒰subscript𝒐𝑖𝒰\bm{o}_{i}\in\mathcal{U} and 𝒐i≠𝒐jsubscript𝒐𝑖subscript𝒐𝑗\bm{o}_{i}\neq\bm{o}_{j} for any i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j, and 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O} denotes the set of all orders. Then, via the estimated reward, the i′superscript𝑖′i^{\prime}-th client in 𝒐𝒐\bm{o} is assigned to an optimized channel from all available available channels as: a^i′,j′​(t)=1subscript^𝑎superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′𝑡1\hat{a}_{i^{\prime},j^{\prime}}(t)=1 and j′=arg⁡maxj∈𝒜⁡ei′,j​(t)superscript𝑗′subscript𝑗𝒜subscript𝑒superscript𝑖′𝑗𝑡j^{\prime}=\arg\max_{j\in\mathcal{A}}e_{i^{\prime},j}(t). After assigning, the selected available channels j′superscript𝑗′j^{\prime} is removed from the set of available available channels 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Until all clients finish the channel selection. Finally, we update 𝒂​(t)𝒂𝑡\bm{a}(t) as the better one in {𝒂​(t−1),𝒂^​(t)}𝒂𝑡1bold-^𝒂𝑡\{\bm{a}(t-1),\bm{\hat{a}}(t)\}. We can note that with an increasing communication round t𝑡t, the estimated reward ei,j​(t)subscript𝑒𝑖𝑗𝑡e_{i,j}(t) will be more accurate and the performance of the GMBA algorithm will improve. In the following theorem, we will show the superiority of the proposed GMBA algorithm.

Theorem 2.

The set of all greedy matching results ℛℛ\mathcal{R} includes at least an optimal matching, i.e., 𝐚⋆∈ℛsuperscript𝐚⋆ℛ\bm{a}^{\star}\in\mathcal{R}.

Proof:

First, we assume that no client selects its best channel in the optimal matching 𝒂⋆superscript𝒂⋆\bm{a}^{\star}. From [39], we can find an equal matching with the same result with 𝒂⋆superscript𝒂⋆\bm{a}^{\star}, which is in conflict with the optimal claim. We can conclude that there is at least one client who selects its best channel (i.e., the channel with the highest estimated reward) in the optimal matching 𝒂⋆superscript𝒂⋆\bm{a}^{\star} or its equal matching. Besides, the matching results for the set of clients that selecting their best available channels is not important under the greedy algorithm, because each client will choose a different channel. Hence, we can first process the set of clients that selects their best available channels, and then the remaining clients can reselect their best available channels within the remaining available channels. Repeating the procedure, we can obtain an order 𝒐𝒐\bm{o} that yields 𝒂⋆superscript𝒂⋆\bm{a}^{\star} through the greedy algorithm.

Via this theorem, we can note that if ei,j​(t+1)subscript𝑒𝑖𝑗𝑡1e_{i,j}(t+1) is unchanged, finding the optimal matching 𝒂⋆superscript𝒂⋆\bm{a}^{\star} by the greedy algorithm requires searching over all U!𝑈U! permutations for U𝑈U clients. However, we cannot obtain the mean reward directly, and thus ei,j​(t+1)subscript𝑒𝑖𝑗𝑡1e_{i,j}(t+1) varies at different communication rounds. We can note that with a comparable large t𝑡t, the performance of the proposed GMBA algorithm will be close to the optimal value, where more results can be found in the experimental results.

V-C Complexity Analysis

At the beginning of each communication round, the server will calculate estimated rewards for all clients and available channels, which has a O​(U​N)𝑂𝑈𝑁O(UN) time complexity. The computational complexity of the Hungarian algorithm and the greedy matching algorithm with a given order 𝒐𝒐\bm{o} can be given by O​(U​N)𝑂𝑈𝑁O(UN) and O​(U​N)𝑂𝑈𝑁O(UN), respectively. Then, for the Hungarian algorithm, we need at most (N−1)​U𝑁1𝑈(N-1)U pruning operations. Therefore, under T𝑇T communication rounds, the overall computational complexity of the OM and the GMBA algorithm can be expressed as O​(T​(N−1)​U3​N2)𝑂𝑇𝑁1superscript𝑈3superscript𝑁2O\left(T(N-1)U^{3}N^{2}\right) and O​(T​U2​N2)𝑂𝑇superscript𝑈2superscript𝑁2O\left(TU^{2}N^{2}\right), respectively. From expressions, we can notice that the relationship between computational complexity and the key variables, i.e., N𝑁N, U𝑈U and T𝑇T, is not exponential. Furthermore, the client scheduling is conducted in the server side and can be decomposed into multithreaded parallel computing tasks. Therefore, our proposed client scheduling schemes will be able to work well when N𝑁N, U𝑈U and T𝑇T go large.

VI Performance Evaluation

VI-A Feasibility and Regret Bound for MAMAB Algorithm

In this subsection, we first show Algorithm 1 can satisfy the selection utility constraint for any minimum selection fraction vector and the constraints are satisfied as long as the virtual queue system defined is mean rate stable. Then, we show that the proposed algorithm also achieves the rate-optimality, i,e,. the logarithmic growth of the expected total regret with respect to time log⁡T𝑇\log T. We state the first result as follows.

Theorem 3.

The proposed Algorithm 1 is feasibility-optimal. Specifically, for any minimum selection fraction, the virtual queue system defined is strongly stable.

Proof:

See Appendix B.

Theorem 3 implies that the constraints may be unsatisfied even after a sufficiently long time. This theorem states that our proposed algorithm can satisfy the participating ratio constraint as long as the requirement is feasible.

Then, we aim to bound the expected regret of the proposed algorithm. Let μi,jsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑗\mu_{i,j} denote the average reward of the i𝑖i-th client with the j𝑗j-th channel. Let 𝒂⋆superscript𝒂⋆\bm{a}^{\star} and μ⋆superscript𝜇⋆\mu^{\star} denote an optimal bipartite matching result (i.e., 𝒂⋆=arg⁡max𝒂⁡mini∈𝒰​∑j∈𝒩ai,j​μi,jsuperscript𝒂⋆subscript𝒂subscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑗𝒩subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗\bm{a}^{\star}=\arg\max_{\bm{a}}\min_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}a_{i,j}\mu_{i,j}) and the expected reward corresponding to 𝒂⋆superscript𝒂⋆\bm{a}^{\star} (i.e., μ⋆=max𝒂⁡mini∈𝒰​∑j∈𝒩ai,j​μi,jsuperscript𝜇⋆subscript𝒂subscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑗𝒩subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗\mu^{\star}=\max_{\bm{a}}\min_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}a_{i,j}\mu_{i,j}), respectively. Then, we define

Δmin≜μ⋆−max𝒂,𝒂≠𝒂⋆⁡{mini∈𝒰​∑j∈𝒩ai,j​μi,j}≜subscriptΔminsuperscript𝜇⋆subscript𝒂𝒂superscript𝒂⋆subscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑗𝒩subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\Delta_{\text{min}}\triangleq\mu^{\star}-\max_{\bm{a},\bm{a}\neq\bm{a}^{\star}}\left\{\min_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}a_{i,j}\mu_{i,j}\right\} (13)

and

Δmax≜μ⋆−min𝒂⁡{mini∈𝒰​∑j∈𝒩ai,j​μi,j}.≜subscriptΔmaxsuperscript𝜇⋆subscript𝒂subscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑗𝒩subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\Delta_{\text{max}}\triangleq\mu^{\star}-\min_{\bm{a}}\left\{\min_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}a_{i,j}\mu_{i,j}\right\}. (14)

Under the assumption Δmin>0subscriptΔmin0\Delta_{\text{min}}>0, we have the following expected regret shown in Theorem 4.

Theorem 4.

Let ε𝜀\varepsilon be the precision of the bipartite matching algorithm and choose ε𝜀\varepsilon such that ε<Δmin−Qmax𝜀subscriptΔminsubscript𝑄max\varepsilon<\Delta_{\emph{min}}-Q_{\emph{max}}. Then, the expected regret of Algorithm 1 is given by

Rregsubscript𝑅reg\displaystyle R_{\emph{reg}} ≤Δmax​(4​V2​N​(U+2)​log⁡T(Δmin−Qmax−ε)2+(2​U+1)​N),absentsubscriptΔmax4superscript𝑉2𝑁𝑈2𝑇superscriptsubscriptΔminsubscript𝑄max𝜀22𝑈1𝑁\displaystyle\leq\Delta_{\emph{max}}\Bigg{(}\frac{4V^{2}N(U+2)\log T}{(\Delta_{\emph{min}}-Q_{\emph{max}}-\varepsilon)^{2}}+(2U+1)N\Bigg{)}, (15)

where Qmaxsubscript𝑄maxQ_{\emph{max}} is the maximum value of Qi​(t)subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡Q_{i}(t), i∈𝒰𝑖𝒰i\in\mathcal{U}.

Proof:

See Appendix C.

It is obvious that the upper bound for the proposed algorithm is quite appealing as it separately captures the impact of the utility selection constraint and the impact of the uncertainty in the mean rewards for any finite number of communication rounds T𝑇T. Specifically, when V𝑉V is small, the proposed algorithm gives a higher priority to meeting the client participating ratio requirement by favoring a match with a larger virtual queue length, even if this match has a small estimated reward. Similarly, a larger V𝑉V leads to a smaller regret, but it will take a longer time to converge which satisfies the participating ratio constraint. The part of O​(N​log⁡T)𝑂𝑁𝑇O(N\log T) in this regret corresponds to the notion of regret in typical MAMAB problems and is attributed to the cost that needs to be paid in the learning/exploration process.

VI-B Convergence Analysis for the Proposed MAMAB based FL

We note that the wireless channel will influence the transmitting time for each client, and will lead to different participating clients of aggregation in each communication round. However, it is not easy to obtain the set of participating clients of aggregation in each communication round due to the varying channel, the unknown interference and the stochastic scheduling scheme. Thus, we define the set of participating clients of the t𝑡t-th aggregation as ℬ​(t)ℬ𝑡\mathcal{B}(t) and derive a convergence bound based on this predefined set.

We first mention the customary assumptions required for both convex and non-convex settings.

Assumption 1.

We assume the following for all i𝑖i:

  • 2)

    For any i𝑖i, Fi​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F_{i}(\cdot) is λmsubscript𝜆𝑚\lambda_{m}-smooth for m𝑚m-class samples for all clients, where m∈{1,…,M}𝑚1…𝑀m\in\{1,\ldots,M\};

  • 3)

    For the learning rate η𝜂\eta and λmax=maxm∈{1,…,M}⁡λmsubscript𝜆maxsubscript𝑚1…𝑀subscript𝜆𝑚\lambda_{\emph{max}}=\max_{m\in\{1,\ldots,M\}}\lambda_{m}, η​λmax<1𝜂subscript𝜆max1\eta\lambda_{\emph{max}}<1.

Based on Assumption 1, we further analyze the convergence performance of the proposed client scheduling scheme.

If we assume that the loss function Fi​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰F_{i}(\bm{w}) of the i𝑖i-th client is convex, the convergence bound of Algorithm 1 is given by

Proof:

See Appendix D.

From Theorem 5, we can note that the proposed client scheduling scheme is converged when there exists |ℬ​(t)|>0ℬ𝑡0|\mathcal{B}(t)|>0. If all clients have a good enough channel and can upload their local models to the server successfully, the system can achieve a satisfied learning performance. If |ℬ​(t)|=0ℬ𝑡0|\mathcal{B}(t)|=0, it means that the t𝑡t-th communication round has failed and is missing in the whole process. Moreover, the convergence bound is also governed by the maximum participant probability of aggregation ℙmaxsubscriptℙmax\mathds{P}_{\text{max}}, which is determined by the computation capacity and channel quality for all clients. Hence, at each communication round, if all clients can upload their training models successfully, the FL system will obtain a satisfied performance.

Moreover, we also provide a convergence bound for the case of non-convex loss functions in the following theorem.

Theorem 6.

If we assume that the loss function Fi​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰F_{i}(\bm{w}) of the i𝑖i-th client is non-convex, the convergence bound of Algorithm 1 is given by

+λmax​ℙmax​(1−ℙmax)​∑i∈𝒰∑j∈𝒰|𝒟i|2​|𝒟j|2​(Θi2​(τ)+Θj2​(τ))η​(1−η​λmax2)​|𝒟|2​|ℬ|2​Dmin2subscript𝜆maxsubscriptℙmax1subscriptℙmaxsubscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑗𝒰superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗2superscriptsubscriptΘ𝑖2𝜏superscriptsubscriptΘ𝑗2𝜏𝜂1𝜂subscript𝜆max2superscript𝒟2superscriptℬ2superscriptsubscript𝐷min2\displaystyle\quad+\frac{\lambda_{\emph{max}}\mathds{P}_{\emph{max}}(1-\mathds{P}_{\emph{max}})\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\sum\limits_{j\in\mathcal{U}}|\mathcal{D}_{i}|^{2}|\mathcal{D}_{j}|^{2}\left(\Theta_{i}^{2}(\tau)+\Theta_{j}^{2}(\tau)\right)}{\eta\left(1-\frac{\eta\lambda_{\emph{max}}}{2}\right)|\mathcal{D}|^{2}|\mathcal{B}|^{2}D_{\emph{min}}^{2}}

Proof:

See Appendix E.

The bound in Theorem 6 implies that our proposed algorithm can achieve an overall convergence rate of O​(1T)𝑂1𝑇O\left(\frac{1}{T}\right) for non-convex losses. Similarly, when all clients can upload their training models successfully and the local epoch τ=1𝜏1\tau=1, i.e., equal to centralized learning, the FL system will obtain the best performance.

VII Experimental Results

VII-A Experimental Settings

We examine the results of the proposed algorithm, specifically the performance of Algorithm 1, on the following two neural networks and datasets: multi-layer perceptron (MLP) with FahionMNIST and convolutional neural network (CNN) with CIFAR-101010.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    MLP with FahionMNIST. MLP is conducted on the FahionMNIST dataset [40]. MLP is a simple feed-forward deep neural network with ReLU units and softmax of 10 classes (corresponding to the 10 categories) with cross-entropy loss. FahionMNIST is a dataset of fashion products consisting of 60,0006000060,000 training examples and 10,0001000010,000 testing examples formatted as 28×\times28 size gray scale images;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    CNN with CIFAR-101010. The CNN model consists of three 3×3333\times 3 convolution layers (the first with 646464 filters, the second with 128128128 filters, the third with 256256256 filters, each followed with 2×2222\times 2 max pooling and ReLu activation), two fully connected layers (the first with 128128128 units, the second with 256256256 units, each followed with ReLu activation), and a final softmax output layer. The CIFAR-101010 dataset [41] consists of 60,0006000060,000 color images in 101010 object classes such as deer, airplane, and dog with 6,00060006,000 images included per class. The complete dataset is pre-divided into 50,0005000050,000 training images and 10,0001000010,000 test images. For CIFAR-101010, we also use softmax of 10 classes with cross-entropy loss.

To evaluate the performance, we compare the proposed algorithm, i.e., MAMAB-OM (modified Hungarian algorithm) and MAMAB-GMBA (Algorithm 2), with the following baselines:

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Random Scheduling [17]: In each communication round, the BS uniformly select U𝑈U associated clients at random for parameter update, each selected client is assigned a dedicated subchannel to transmit the trained parameter.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Round Robin [17]: The BS arranges all the clients into ⌈UN⌉𝑈𝑁\lceil\frac{U}{N}\rceil groups and consecutively assigns each group to access the radio channels and update their parameters per communication round.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Single-UCB [23]: The BS selects a subset consisting of N𝑁N clients from U𝑈U associated clients with the maximum total rewards via a single UCB policy.

Besides, simulations are performed in a square area of 2,000×2,000200020002,000\times 2,000 m2superscript𝑚2m^{2}. Both available channels and clients are uniformly distributed in this plane. Unless otherwise stated, the system parameters are set as follows. We set the number of clients to 101010, the number of available available channels to 444, the degree of non-IID to 0.80.80.8 and the number of local iterations to 555, respectively. For the wireless channel, we set the bandwidth BUsuperscript𝐵UB^{\text{U}} and BDsuperscript𝐵DB^{\text{D}} to 151515 KHz, the transmission power of available channels to 232323 dBm, Gaussian white noise power to −107107-107 dBm, and path loss exponent model to P​L𝑃𝐿PL, where P​L​[d​B]=128.1+37.6​log⁡(k)𝑃𝐿delimited-[]𝑑𝐵128.137.6𝑘PL[dB]=128.1+37.6\log(k) with k𝑘k representing the distance in km. The uplink and downlink interferences are generated by the Gaussian distribution with different variances. The computing capability fi​(t)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑡f_{i}(t) of each client is uniformly distributed in [10∗i+10,100∗i+30]10𝑖10100𝑖30[10*i+10,100*i+30] KHz, and the maximal interval dmax=2subscript𝑑max2d_{\text{max}}=2 seconds for the CIFAR-101010 and dmax=5subscript𝑑max5d_{\text{max}}=5 seconds for the FahionMNIST, respectively. In addition, the required DP parameters for all clients are set to ϵi=25subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖25\epsilon_{i}=25 and δi=0.001,∀i∈𝒰formulae-sequencesubscript𝛿𝑖0.001for-all𝑖𝒰\delta_{i}=0.001,\forall i\in\mathcal{U}, respectively. In Algorithm 1, we adopt various V𝑉V, i.e., V=1𝑉1V=1, V=10𝑉10V=10 and V=100𝑉100V=100, and T0=100subscript𝑇0100T_{0}=100 to balance the learning performance and training delay.

VII-B Evaluation of the Proposed Algorithm

Fig. 2 illustrates the test accuracy of our proposed MAMAB algorithms with different values of V𝑉V, and random scheduling on MLP with FahionMNIST. As seen from Fig. 2(a), the proposed MAMAB algorithm using different values of V𝑉V achieve a better accuracy than the random one. We can also observe that the performance gap decreases as the number of communication rounds increases. The reason is that the test accuracy is close to the limitation with a sufficiently large number of communication rounds. Moreover, the value of V𝑉V is a key factor to balance the trade-off between the latency and the client selection rate. As shown in Fig. 2(b), our proposed MAMAB algorithms with larger values of V𝑉V bring out lower latencies. The intuition is that a larger V𝑉V can lead to a higher consideration for the FL training delay but a smaller consideration for the learning performance. From Figs. 2(a) and  2(b), we can also notice that our proposed MAMAB algorithms with V=1𝑉1V=1 show the better test accuracy than the one with V=10𝑉10V=10, but lead to higher latencies. The reason is the trade-off between the latency and training accuracy, that is: guaranteeing the chosen rate for each client can achieve a satisfied accuracy but with larger latency for a long term, while reducing the latency per round but degrading the training accuracy.

In addition, we also evaluate this MLP based FL system on FahionMNIST by setting a small privacy level, i.e, ϵi=0.8,∀i∈𝒰formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖0.8for-all𝑖𝒰\epsilon_{i}=0.8,\forall i\in\mathcal{U} and a small data sampling size, i.e., bi=10,∀i∈𝒰formulae-sequencesubscript𝑏𝑖10for-all𝑖𝒰b_{i}=10,\forall i\in\mathcal{U}. Similar to Fig. 2, our proposed MAMAB algorithms using different values of V𝑉V achieve a better accuracy than the random one in Fig. 3(a). Meanwhile, our proposed MAMAB algorithms with larger values of V𝑉V incur lower latencies as shown in Fig. 3(b). Besides, we can also calculate the composition of leakage and obtain the maximum privacy leakage among all clients, i.e., ϵ¯=maxi∈𝒰⁡ϵ¯i=12.05¯italic-ϵsubscript𝑖𝒰subscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖12.05\overline{\epsilon}=\max_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\overline{\epsilon}_{i}=12.05 using (6). Due to the high privacy level, i.e., a small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, we can observe that the training performance in Fig. 3(a) is worse than that in Fig. 2(a).

Fig. 4 shows aggregation times achieved at a variety of maximum tolerable delay of our proposed MAMAB algorithms on FashionMNIST and CIFAR-101010, respectively. We see that our proposed MAMAB-OM algorithm can achieve more aggregation times than the MAMAB-GMBA one. Furthermore, with a larger V𝑉V, our proposed algorithms can complete more training epochs with a fixed maximum tolerable delay. The reason is that a larger V𝑉V can lead to a higher consideration for the FL training delay.

Then the client selection rates for each client with our proposed MAMAB-OM algorithm under various values of V𝑉V are shown in Fig. 5. In Figs. 5(a) and 5(b), we consider two different DP schemes: 1) uniform, where all clients adopt the same DP parameter, i.e, ϵi=25subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖25\epsilon_{i}=25 and δ=0.001𝛿0.001\delta=0.001, 2) non-uniform, where the DP parameter for the i𝑖ith client is set to ϵi=5∗(⌊i−12⌋+3)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖5𝑖123\epsilon_{i}=5*(\lfloor\frac{i-1}{2}\rfloor+3) and δ=0.001𝛿0.001\delta=0.001. From Fig. 5(b), we can note that when i𝑖i is small, the privacy level is high and then leads to a small selection requirement. Furthermore, we can observe that the value of V𝑉V has a significant effect on the selection rate for each client. This result reveals the tradeoff between the guarantee for the selection rate and the training latency.

VII-C Comparison of Different Scheduling Policies

To show the effectiveness of Algorithm 1, we compare our proposed MAMAB-OM and MAMAB-GMBA algorithms with a set of baseline policies, i.e., Random Scheduling, Round Robin, Single-UCB-0.010.010.01 and Single-UCB-0.10.10.1.

Fig. 6 shows the changes of test accuracy along with the communication rounds t𝑡t using our proposed MAMAB algorithms and baseline policies on FashionMNIST and CIFAR-101010, respectively. We can find that the proposed MAMAB algorithms achieves a better performance than baseline policies. The reason/intuition is that the proposed MAMAB algorithms keep learning the statistical information of each client in the execution process and leverages a tradeoff between the exploitation of learned knowledge and the exploration of more potential actions. Although Single-UCB-0.010.010.01 and Single-UCB-0.10.10.1 also have the ability to exploit the statistical information of channel state and computation capacity for each client, but they cannot overcome the difference of interference for different clients.

Fig. 7 illustrates the changes of cumulative delay along with the communication rounds t𝑡t using our proposed MAMAB algorithms and baseline policies on FashionMNIST and CIFAR-101010, respectively. As seen from Fig. 7, the proposed MAMAB algorithms achieve lower cumulative delay than baseline policies and the superiority is more and more obvious with increasing number of communication rounds. The advantage of our proposed MAMAB algorithms is twofold: Firstly, our proposed MAMAB algorithms schedules the clients with better channel conditions and computation capabilities with an appropriate matching according to the estimated reward, and thus can reduce the per round latency compared to baseline policies. Secondly, our proposed MAMAB algorithms achieve a better trade-off between the latency per round and the training performance.

VIII Conclusion

In this paper, we have developed a realistic implementation of FL over a wireless network with imbalanced resources and DP requirements among clients, i.e., stochastic training frequencies, DP guarantee, uncertain interference of wireless channels, non-IID data and various data sizes for clients. Then, we have formulated the joint client selection and channel assignment problem as a MAMAB framework that is to minimize the time delay while taking FL convergence into account. We have developed the convergence bound for each client to derive a client participating ratio to constrain the above MAMAB problem. In order to address this constraint, we involved a virtual queue inspired by the Lyapunov optimization. We then have adopted the UCB method to estimate model upload time for each client and channels to convert this MAMAB to a max-min weighted bipartite graph matching problem, and then proposed the modified Hungarian and GMBA algorithms, to schedule clients at each communication round. An upper bound on the expected regret of the proposed MAMAB based FL has been derived and shows a linear growth over the logarithm of communication rounds, justifying its theoretical feasibility. Extensive experimental results have been provided to validate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithms, and outperforms state-of-the-art baseline scheduling policies. We can observe that if the maximum waiting time is large enough to ensure all the clients’ models participate in the aggregation of every communication round, we can obtain the optimal training performance. A problem of interest for future work in this area is to establish an optimal trade-off between the performance and latency.

Based on Theorem 4.5 in [35] and Lemma 1 in [42], for any ζ>0𝜁0\zeta>0, we can make the following inequalities that hold:

𝔼​{∑i∈𝒮​(t)r~i​(t)|𝑸​(t)}≥∑i∈𝒮​(t)Qi​(t)​(βi+ϵ).𝔼conditional-setsubscript𝑖𝒮𝑡subscript~𝑟𝑖𝑡𝑸𝑡subscript𝑖𝒮𝑡subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡subscript𝛽𝑖italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}(t)}\widetilde{r}_{i}(t)|\bm{Q}(t)\right\}\geq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}(t)}Q_{i}(t)(\beta_{i}+\epsilon). (30)

Therefore, 𝔼​{L​(𝑸​(t+1))−L​(𝑸​(t))|𝑸​(t)}≤U2+U​V−ζ​∑i∈𝒮​(t)Qi​(t)𝔼conditional-set𝐿𝑸𝑡1𝐿𝑸𝑡𝑸𝑡𝑈2𝑈𝑉𝜁subscript𝑖𝒮𝑡subscript𝑄𝑖𝑡\mathbb{E}\{L(\bm{Q}(t+1))-L(\bm{Q}(t))|\bm{Q}(t)\}\leq\frac{U}{2}+UV-\zeta\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}(t)}Q_{i}(t). Finally, invoking Theorem 4.5 in [35] (Lyapunov Drift Theorem) and with the condition that ζ>0𝜁0\zeta>0, we can conclude that all the virtual queues defined is not only mean rate stable, but also strongly stable, i.e.,

limT→∞sup1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​{mini∈𝒰⁡r~i​(t)}≤U​(1+2​V)2​ζ<∞.subscript→𝑇supremum1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼subscript𝑖𝒰subscript~𝑟𝑖𝑡𝑈12𝑉2𝜁\displaystyle\lim_{T\rightarrow\infty}\sup\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\left\{\min_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\widetilde{r}_{i}(t)\right\}\leq\frac{U(1+2V)}{2\zeta}<\infty. (31)

This completes the proof. □□\hfill\square

Appendix D Proof of Theorem 5

We define a subset ℬℬ\mathcal{B} with a size |ℬ|ℬ|\mathcal{B}|, which is determined by user selection policy, available computation resources and channel states, and ℬℬ\mathcal{B} is changed during the whole training process. Therefore, 𝔼​{F​(𝒘ℬ​(t))−F​(𝒘​(t))}≤L2​𝔼​{‖𝒘ℬ​(t)−𝒘​(t)‖2}𝔼𝐹superscript𝒘ℬ𝑡𝐹𝒘𝑡𝐿2𝔼superscriptnormsuperscript𝒘ℬ𝑡𝒘𝑡2\mathbb{E}\left\{F(\bm{w}^{\mathcal{B}}(t))-F(\bm{w}(t))\right\}\leq\frac{L}{2}\mathbb{E}\left\{\|\bm{w}^{\mathcal{B}}(t)-\bm{w}(t)\|^{2}\right\}. Then, we can obtain

𝔼​{‖𝒘ℬ​(t)−𝒘​(t)‖2}=𝔼​{‖∑i∈ℬ|𝒟i|​(𝒘~i​(t)−𝒘​(t))∑i∈ℬ|𝒟i|‖2}𝔼superscriptnormsuperscript𝒘ℬ𝑡𝒘𝑡2𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝑖ℬsubscript𝒟𝑖subscriptbold-~𝒘𝑖𝑡𝒘𝑡subscript𝑖ℬsubscript𝒟𝑖2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{\|\bm{w}^{\mathcal{B}}(t)-\bm{w}(t)\|^{2}\right\}=\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\|\frac{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}}{|\mathcal{D}_{i}|}(\bm{\widetilde{w}}_{i}(t)-\bm{w}(t))}{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}}|\mathcal{D}_{i}|}\right\|^{2}\right\} (47)

According to [18, 44], we can obtain

𝔼​{F​(𝒘ℬ​(t))−F​(𝒘⋆)}≤1T​(η​φ−ρ​Ξ​(τ)+maxt∈𝒯⁡Ξ^t​(τ)τ​ε02),𝔼𝐹superscript𝒘ℬ𝑡𝐹superscript𝒘⋆1𝑇𝜂𝜑𝜌Ξ𝜏subscript𝑡𝒯subscript^Ξ𝑡𝜏𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜀02\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{F(\bm{w}^{\mathcal{B}}(t))-F(\bm{w}^{\star})\right\}\leq\frac{1}{T\left(\eta\varphi-\frac{\rho\Xi(\tau)+\max_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\widehat{\Xi}_{t}(\tau)}{\tau\varepsilon_{0}^{2}}\right)}, (59)

where ρ≜ω​(1−λmax2)≜𝜌𝜔1subscript𝜆max2\rho\triangleq\omega\left(1-\frac{\lambda_{\text{max}}}{2}\right), ω≜mint∈𝒯⁡1‖𝒘ℬ​(t)−𝒘⋆‖≜𝜔subscript𝑡𝒯1normsuperscript𝒘ℬ𝑡superscript𝒘⋆\omega\triangleq\min_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\frac{1}{\|\bm{w}^{\mathcal{B}}(t)-\bm{w}^{\star}\|} and ε0≜mint∈𝒯⁡1+1+4​η​ρ​T2​τ​(ρ​Ξ​(τ)+|ℬ​(t)|)2​η​ρ​T​τ≜subscript𝜀0subscript𝑡𝒯114𝜂𝜌superscript𝑇2𝜏𝜌Ξ𝜏ℬ𝑡2𝜂𝜌𝑇𝜏\varepsilon_{0}\triangleq\min_{t\in\mathcal{T}}{\frac{1+\sqrt{1+4\eta\rho T^{2}\tau(\rho\Xi(\tau)+|\mathcal{B}(t)|)}}{2\eta\rho T\tau}}. This completes the proof. □□\hfill\square

Appendix E Proof of Theorem 6

First, using the λmaxsubscript𝜆max\lambda_{\text{max}}-Lipschitz smoothness, we can obtain the following inequality:

F​(𝒘ℬ​(t))−F​(𝒘^​(t))𝐹superscript𝒘ℬ𝑡𝐹bold-^𝒘𝑡\displaystyle F(\bm{w}^{\mathcal{B}}(t))-F(\bm{\widehat{w}}(t)) (60)
≤λmax​(‖𝒘ℬ​(t)−𝒘​(t)‖2+‖𝒘​(t)−𝒘^​(t)‖2).absentsubscript𝜆maxsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝒘ℬ𝑡𝒘𝑡2superscriptnorm𝒘𝑡bold-^𝒘𝑡2\displaystyle\leq\lambda_{\text{max}}\left(\|\bm{w}^{\mathcal{B}}(t)-\bm{w}(t)\|^{2}+\|\bm{w}(t)-\bm{\widehat{w}}(t)\|^{2}\right).

Substituting (51) and (55) into (60), we can obtain

F​(𝒘ℬ​(t))−F​(𝒘^​(t))𝐹superscript𝒘ℬ𝑡𝐹bold-^𝒘𝑡\displaystyle F(\bm{w}^{\mathcal{B}}(t))-F(\bm{\widehat{w}}(t)) (61)
≤λmax​ℙmax​(1−ℙmax)​∑i∈𝒰∑j∈𝒰|𝒟i|2​|𝒟j|2​(Θi2​(τ)+Θj2​(τ))|𝒟|2​|ℬ|2​Dmin2absentsubscript𝜆maxsubscriptℙmax1subscriptℙmaxsubscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑗𝒰superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗2superscriptsubscriptΘ𝑖2𝜏superscriptsubscriptΘ𝑗2𝜏superscript𝒟2superscriptℬ2superscriptsubscript𝐷min2\displaystyle\leq\frac{\lambda_{\text{max}}\mathds{P}_{\text{max}}(1-\mathds{P}_{\text{max}})\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\sum\limits_{j\in\mathcal{U}}|\mathcal{D}_{i}|^{2}|\mathcal{D}_{j}|^{2}\left(\Theta_{i}^{2}(\tau)+\Theta_{j}^{2}(\tau)\right)}{|\mathcal{D}|^{2}|\mathcal{B}|^{2}D_{\text{min}}^{2}}
+λmax​Ξ​(τ).subscript𝜆maxΞ𝜏\displaystyle\quad+\lambda_{\text{max}}\Xi(\tau).

Due to the λmaxsubscript𝜆max\lambda_{\text{max}}-Lipschitz smoothness, we can obtain

F​(𝒘^​(t))−F​(𝒘^​(t−1))≤−η​(1−η​λmax2)​∑j=0τ−1∇F​(𝒘^j​(t−1)).𝐹bold-^𝒘𝑡𝐹bold-^𝒘𝑡1𝜂1𝜂subscript𝜆max2superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝜏1∇𝐹superscriptbold-^𝒘𝑗𝑡1\displaystyle F(\bm{\widehat{w}}(t))-F(\bm{\widehat{w}}(t-1))\leq-\eta\left(1-\frac{\eta\lambda_{\text{max}}}{2}\right)\sum_{j=0}^{\tau-1}\nabla F\left(\bm{\widehat{w}}^{j}(t-1)\right). (62)

We can note that 𝒘ℬ​(t−1)=𝒘^​(t−1)superscript𝒘ℬ𝑡1bold-^𝒘𝑡1\bm{w}^{\mathcal{B}}(t-1)=\bm{\widehat{w}}(t-1) at the beginning of each communication round. Thus, we have

F​(𝒘ℬ​(t))−F​(𝒘ℬ​(t−1))𝐹superscript𝒘ℬ𝑡𝐹superscript𝒘ℬ𝑡1\displaystyle F\left(\bm{w}^{\mathcal{B}}(t)\right)-F\left(\bm{w}^{\mathcal{B}}(t-1)\right) (63)
≤F​(𝒘ℬ​(t))−F​(𝒘^​(t))+F​(𝒘^​(t))−F​(𝒘^​(t−1))absent𝐹superscript𝒘ℬ𝑡𝐹bold-^𝒘𝑡𝐹bold-^𝒘𝑡𝐹bold-^𝒘𝑡1\displaystyle\leq F\left(\bm{w}^{\mathcal{B}}(t)\right)-F\left(\bm{\widehat{w}}(t)\right)+F\left(\bm{\widehat{w}}(t)\right)-F\left(\bm{\widehat{w}}(t-1)\right)
≤λmax​ℙmax​(1−ℙmax)​∑i∈𝒰∑j∈𝒰|𝒟i|2​|𝒟j|2​(Θi2​(τ)+Θj2​(τ))|𝒟|2​|ℬ|2​Dmin2absentsubscript𝜆maxsubscriptℙmax1subscriptℙmaxsubscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑗𝒰superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗2superscriptsubscriptΘ𝑖2𝜏superscriptsubscriptΘ𝑗2𝜏superscript𝒟2superscriptℬ2superscriptsubscript𝐷min2\displaystyle\leq\frac{\lambda_{\text{max}}\mathds{P}_{\text{max}}(1-\mathds{P}_{\text{max}})\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\sum\limits_{j\in\mathcal{U}}|\mathcal{D}_{i}|^{2}|\mathcal{D}_{j}|^{2}\left(\Theta_{i}^{2}(\tau)+\Theta_{j}^{2}(\tau)\right)}{|\mathcal{D}|^{2}|\mathcal{B}|^{2}D_{\text{min}}^{2}}
+λmax​Ξ​(τ)−η​(1−η​λmax2)​∑j=0τ−1∇F​(𝒘^j​(t−1)).subscript𝜆maxΞ𝜏𝜂1𝜂subscript𝜆max2superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝜏1∇𝐹superscriptbold-^𝒘𝑗𝑡1\displaystyle\quad+\lambda_{\text{max}}\Xi(\tau)-\eta\left(1-\frac{\eta\lambda_{\text{max}}}{2}\right)\sum_{j=0}^{\tau-1}\nabla F\left(\bm{\widehat{w}}^{j}(t-1)\right).

Now summing above equation over t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\ldots,T and rearranging the terms yield that

1T​∑t=1T∑j=0τ−1∇F​(𝒘^j​(t−1))≤F​(𝒘​(0))−F​(𝒘⋆)T​η​(1−η​λmax2)1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝜏1∇𝐹superscriptbold-^𝒘𝑗𝑡1𝐹𝒘0𝐹superscript𝒘⋆𝑇𝜂1𝜂subscript𝜆max2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{j=0}^{\tau-1}\nabla F\left(\bm{\widehat{w}}^{j}(t-1)\right)\leq\frac{F\left(\bm{w}(0)\right)-F\left(\bm{w}^{\star}\right)}{T\eta\left(1-\frac{\eta\lambda_{\text{max}}}{2}\right)} (64)
+λmax​ℙmax​(1−ℙmax)​∑i∈𝒰∑j∈𝒰|𝒟i|2​|𝒟j|2​(Θi2​(τ)+Θj2​(τ))η​(1−η​λmax2)​|𝒟|2​|ℬ|2​Dmin2subscript𝜆maxsubscriptℙmax1subscriptℙmaxsubscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑗𝒰superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗2superscriptsubscriptΘ𝑖2𝜏superscriptsubscriptΘ𝑗2𝜏𝜂1𝜂subscript𝜆max2superscript𝒟2superscriptℬ2superscriptsubscript𝐷min2\displaystyle\quad+\frac{\lambda_{\text{max}}\mathds{P}_{\text{max}}(1-\mathds{P}_{\text{max}})\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{U}}\sum\limits_{j\in\mathcal{U}}|\mathcal{D}_{i}|^{2}|\mathcal{D}_{j}|^{2}\left(\Theta_{i}^{2}(\tau)+\Theta_{j}^{2}(\tau)\right)}{\eta\left(1-\frac{\eta\lambda_{\text{max}}}{2}\right)|\mathcal{D}|^{2}|\mathcal{B}|^{2}D_{\text{min}}^{2}}
+λmax​Ξ​(τ)η​(1−η​λmax2).subscript𝜆maxΞ𝜏𝜂1𝜂subscript𝜆max2\displaystyle\quad+\frac{\lambda_{\text{max}}\Xi(\tau)}{\eta\left(1-\frac{\eta\lambda_{\text{max}}}{2}\right)}.

This completes the proof. □□\hfill\square
